monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: Machu Picchu was built by the Inca Emperor Pachacuti in the 15th century.
The construction involved highly skilled Incan engineers, architects, and laborers who utilized advanced building techniques.

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: Machu Picchu is located in the Andes Mountains of Peru, near the town of Aguas Calientes.
The site sits at an altitude of 2,430 meters (7,970 feet) above sea level, overlooking the Urubamba River Valley.

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: Machu Picchu was constructed around 1450 CE during the height of the Inca Empire.
It remained inhabited until the early 16th century, when it was abandoned after the Spanish conquest.

monumentInformation.title: Who Is It Protected By
details: Machu Picchu was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983 for its cultural and architectural significance.
It is protected by the Peruvian Ministry of Culture and various conservation programs that aim to preserve the site.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: Machu Picchu was likely built as a royal estate or religious retreat for Emperor Pachacuti and the Incan elite.
The site is believed to symbolize the Incan connection to nature and the cosmos, featuring temples, terraces, and observatories aligned with celestial events.
